item.title: 11 Things Confirmed for Call Of Duty: Black Ops 7
item.description:
Summary

  • Black Ops 7 introduces a Co-Op Campaign with up to 4 players, set in 2035.
  • The Campaign will feature a 32-player PvE Co-Op mode called Endgame.
  • Players will enjoy true cross-progression across Multiplayer, Zombies, & Campaign, for the first time.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 has been officially announced for some time now, and fans can expect another year led by Treyarch. This time, the game takes players away from the '90s and into the near future of 2035. While fans have been eager for details on Black Ops 7 , Gamescom Opening Night Live has given players their first glimpse of what is to come.

Black Ops 7 officially launches on November 14. While fans still have a little time to wait, Treyarch has released a wealth of information about the impending release. Whether it is Multiplayer, Campaign, or Zombies, Treyarch has provided details on each mode. For those interested, here are some of the details confirmed for Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 .

Black Ops 7 Will Feature a Co-Op Campaign

Players Can Go Solo or Play With up to Four Players

The fact that Black Ops 7 features a Co-Op Campaign has been confirmed for quite a while now, as fans caught a glimpse of it in the Black Ops 7 teaser trailer. But now, Treyarch has shed some light on additional details that fans can sink their teeth into. Black Ops 7 will feature a four-player Co-Op Campaign where players can take on the roles of JSOC: David Mason, Mike Harper, Eric Samuels, and Leilani Tupuola, diving into a mix of linear missions set in the year 2035.

The story revolves around Raul Menendez's return and the discovery of a secret weapon that JSOC is exposed to, leading to the kind of trippy levels that the Black Ops series is known for. With a wide range of locales, including Avalon, Nicaragua, Angola, Los Angeles, and even Japan, players will have a diverse lineup of missions to explore. Whether tackling the Campaign solo or with a squad, the difficulty will scale with the squad size and will feature a total of 11 missions.

Black Ops 7’s Campaign Will Feature a Co-Op Mode Dubbed Endgame

Dive Into a 32-Player PvE Experience

While the initial leaks of a 32-player Campaign mission may have been met with speculation, Black Ops 7's Campaign will indeed feature a Co-Op mode that supports up to 32 players. This mode is called Endgame, an open-world PvE experience that takes place after the end of the Campaign. In Endgame, players can explore Avalon with complete freedom , bringing in their Campaign loadouts, Operators, and unlocked abilities obtained throughout the story.

Here, players can complete Activities, take on Assignments, and fight enemies to upgrade their Operator Combat Rating , which leads to more upgrades for their chosen Operator. Endgame takes an extraction-based approach similar to DMZ , where players can extract weapons, equipment, and more to carry into their next run. However, if they are eliminated, everything is reset, including their Operator Combat Rating. It remains unclear how matchmaking will work in Endgame, or if players will be able to access it before completing the Campaign. Regardless, Endgame adds a new layer of replayability to the Campaign, even if only through this mode.

Global Progression Arrives in the Black Ops 7 Campaign

Earn Weapon XP, Level Up, & Prestige Through the Campaign

Cross progression has been a staple in Call of Duty ever since the debut of Warzone and the Call of Duty HQ, allowing players to level up simultaneously across modes. However, Black Ops 7 will be the first Call of Duty game to feature true cross-progression across Multiplayer, Zombies, Warzone , and even the Campaign. That’s right, players can earn weapon XP to level up their guns , progress through levels to unlock weapons and gear in both Multiplayer and Zombies , and also unlock Weapon Camos by playing the Campaign.

Simply put, the progression system players are already used to in Multiplayer and Zombies is now being brought into the Campaign as well. This means those who jump into the Campaign on day one can level up, earn unlocks for the other modes , and even start working on their Weapon Camo progress. It’s a convenient change, and one that probably should have been implemented much sooner. But that's not all, as the Campaign will also feature its very own Mastery Camos.

Black Ops 7's Multiplayer Features 16 6v6 Maps

Dive into 13 Original Maps & 3 Remasters

6v6 is the heart of Call of Duty’s Multiplayer experience, and players will be pleased to know that Black Ops 7 will launch with 16 total 6v6 maps. Thirteen of these are brand new, while three are remastered classics players will instantly recognize: Raid, Express, and Hijacked from Black Ops 2 .

Another thing worth noting is that these maps won’t feature any doors , which is sure to please players who weren’t fans of the lasting impact Modern Warfare 2019 had on the series by adding them in the first place. While fans are still waiting to hear whether most of these maps will stick to the traditional 3-lane design or mix in more open and enclosed layouts, one thing is certain. Players will battle it out across a wide variety of locations, including the Australian Outback, Japan, Alaska, and more.

New Movement Changes are Coming to Black Ops 7

Wall Jump, the Removal of Tac Sprint, & More

Omnimovement is back in Black Ops 7 , which has long been confirmed by Treyarch. However, Black Ops 7 also brings in some wild changes to movement that some players may be interested in. For starters, players can jump off walls , either to add evasive maneuvers during gunfights or to cross between ledges to avoid falling to their death. Black Ops 7 will also feature a combat roll that lets players reduce fall damage.

As for mode-specific movement abilities, t he Campaign introduces a Mega Jump ability that allows players to traverse great distances, along with some other potential movement abilities that have yet to be revealed. The biggest change to movement, though, is that Tac Sprint will not be usable by default. While players can regain Tac Sprint through a Perk in Multiplayer, its removal by default is sure to please those who found its impact on sprint-to-fire and ADS times frustrating.

New 20v20 Mode is Coming to Black Ops 7

Jump Into 2 Avalon Maps in Skirmish

While not much has been revealed about the Multiplayer modes just yet, one mode that has been confirmed is Skirmish, a 20v20 experience. Players dropping into this large-scale mode can battle it out on one of two Skirmish maps at launch , both of which are set on Avalon.

Skirmish will likely play out similarly to Ground War in terms of scale and gameplay, featuring vehicles that players can drive and pilot. However, it also brings in its own unique mechanics, such as a wingsuit for fast traversal and a grapple hook.

All-New Loadout Details and Mechanics for Black Ops 7

Use 30 Different Weapons, Overclock Equipment, & More

Loadouts are what shape the meta of Call of Duty , and Treyarch has revealed plenty of details for Black Ops 7 . The game will feature 30 total weapons , including returning favorites like the Peacekeeper Mk1. Combat Specialties from Black Ops 6 also make a comeback, this time with the added twist of mixing two Combat Perk Specialties to create a Hybrid Combat Specialty.

Loopable Scorestreaks also return to Black Ops 7 through the use of a Perk. On top of that, players can now overclock their Equipment and Scorestreaks , unlocking additional features the more they’re used. One example Treyarch gave in their official blog post was the ability to cook the Cluster Grenade, along with an added mini-grenade to its cluster effect.

That’s not all, though, as Black Ops 7 also introduces Weapon Prestige for unique rewards, and the option to share custom weapon builds with other players using Build Codes , making it way easier to pass along the best loadouts. Field Upgrades also enter the fray again, with an example being the Active Camo that renders the player semi-invisible.

Carry Forward Returns for Black Ops 7

Black Ops 6 Content Will Be Usable in Black Ops 7

A point of contention for many fans with Modern Warfare 3 was the inclusion of Carry Forward, and with Black Ops 7 releasing just a year after Black Ops 6 , Carry Forward is back in some capacity. Right off the bat, all XP Tokens and GobbleGums from Black Ops 6 will be available for use in Black Ops 7 , so players can stack up on both and take advantage of them once the game fully launches.

Black Ops 6 content, such as weapons, weapon cosmetics, operators, and operator skins, will also carry forward into Black Ops 7 . However, this won’t be available until Season 1, meaning players jumping in during the pre-season will only have access to Black Ops 7 content. Season 1 will also mark the Black Ops 7 and Warzone integration, bringing Black Ops 7 content into Warzone . As far as carry forward content for Warzone goes, all content present in the current version will remain.

Black Ops 7 Will See the Return of Weekly Challenges

Weekly Challenges Reward Weapons, Attachments, & More

One of the highlights of Modern Warfare 3 was the fact that players could look forward to something new each week with the inclusion of Weekly Challenges. While Black Ops 6 abandoned the concept, Treyarch has confirmed that Weekly Challenges are back for Black Ops 7 .

By completing Weekly Challenges in Black Ops 7 , players will earn XP progress, unlock weapons, attachments, scorestreaks, and earn exclusive camos. This is a highly requested feature and will provide frequent free content during Black Ops 7's post-launch support.

Black Ops 7 Will Feature Co-Op Zombies Set in the Dark Aether

Jump Into a Large Map at Launch for Black Ops 7 Zombies

Treyarch has been pretty tight-lipped on most things Zombies-related, but they have confirmed some details about the round-based experience coming at launch. Black Ops 7 Zombies will feature a large-scale map set entirely within the Dark Aether, inspired by the original Tranzit from Black Ops 2 .

Players can play as either the Black Ops 6 Crew or a version of the original Zombies Crew: Dempsey, Nikolai, Takeo, and Richtofen. The launch map will include a Wonder Vehicle for transportation across the map's points of interest. Survival mode also returns , allowing players to jump into separate round-based experiences at each point of interest on the launch map.

item.title: Best Asynchronous Multiplayer Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Asynchronous multiplayer games offer deep strategy in short sessions, seamlessly fitting into busy lives.
  • Games like Through the Ages, RAID: Shadow Legends, and The Battle of Polytopia excel in async play.
  • Chess.com reigns in async chess with Daily Chess mode, top-notch features, and a massive player base.

In a world of gaming that constantly demands split-second reflexes and undivided attention, a different kind of competition has been quietly thriving. Asynchronous multiplayer games have reshaped the digital landscape, offering a compelling alternative for those who crave deep, calculated strategy that fits into the nooks and crannies of a busy life.

Instead of demanding twitch reflexes or marathon sessions, async games let the battles unfold gradually, sometimes over days or weeks. It’s strategy gaming that fits between commutes, meetings, or midnight snacks. For those curious about this form of gaming, here's a ranking of the absolute standout titles that blend seamless async play with deep design, active communities, and replay value.

8 Through The Ages

The Deepest Civilization-Building Experience

  • Platforms: PC, iOS, Android
  • Released: 26 March, 2018
  • Developer: CGE Digital
  • Genre: Strategy

Through the Age s is the digital gold standard for deep, turn-based civilization-building. Adapted from Vlaada Chvatil’s beloved board game, it makes no apologies for its steep learning curve. However, its asynchronous multiplayer is the key that unlocks its brilliance for a modern audience.

Flexible turn timers (from 24 hours to unlimited) make marathon sessions manageable, letting players digest and outthink complex situations in their own time. The gameplay revolves around drafting cards, building wonders, managing resources, and keeping citizens content as players guide their civilization from antiquity to the space age. Every action counts, every military bluff matters, and no two games play the same thanks to a massive pool of event cards.

7 RAID: Shadow Legends

A Visually Stunning Gacha Fueled by Endless Battles

Raid: Shadow Legends
10.0 /10
Released
July 29, 2018

ESRB
t
Platform(s)
Android, iOS, PC
Powered by

RAID: Shadow Legends is a colossus gacha RPG built for those who want their progress to continue even when the phone is on silent. Its Classic Arena is the star asynchronous mode, letting players pit their team of collected champions against the AI-controlled defense teams of rivals while they’re offline.

The result is a constant push-pull of offense and defense, with rewards being at stake every time the app is opened. This clever loop is set against a backdrop of immense content, with over 900 champions, a fully-voiced story campaign, and numerous dungeons and clan bosses to conquer, making the game feel truly endless.

6 The Battle Of Polytopia

The Perfect Bite-Sized Empire Builder

  • Platforms: PC, Nintendo Switch, iOS, Android
  • Released: February 9, 2016
  • Developer: Midjiwan AB
  • Genres: Strategy, Simulation, Action

The Battle of Polytopia distills the sprawling 4X empire builder into a bite-sized, approachable strategy game that’s perfect for asynchronous play. Its core async feature is a generous 24-hour turn timer that lets friends and strangers wage continent-spanning wars one decision at a time, without the stress of coordinating live sessions.

Each match pits quirky “tribes” against one another on cute, procedurally generated maps. While the art is bright and the rules are straightforward, Polytopia rewards cunning with a tech tree, city upgrades, and multiple winning conditions. Multiplayer modes are robust, supporting matchmaking, friend challenges, and even local Pass & Play.

5 Super Auto Pets

Deceptively Deep And Endlessly Chill Auto-Battles

Super Auto Pets
Strategy
Systems
Released
February 24, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
e
Platform(s)
Microsoft Windows, iOS, Android, macOS, Linux
Powered by

Super Auto Pets reimagines the auto-battler for the async crowd, offering a timer-free “Arena Mode” that lets players face off against static “ghost” teams drawn from the wider community. Players can build a team of quirky animals, optimize synergies, and then battle snapshots of real opponents, and no scheduling is required. It’s a chill, endlessly replayable format that fits perfectly around daily routines.

The absence of wait times or live lobbies is the secret weapon. Gamers can queue up as many matches as desired, tweaking lineups and chasing that ten-win streak at any pace. A “Versus” mode offers synchronous play for those craving direct competition, but it’s the timer-less, ghost-driven Arena that made Super Auto Pets a viral hit.

4 Wingspan

A Serene And Strategic Masterpiece

5 Images
5 Images
Wingspan
Digital Card Game
Board Game
Systems
Released
September 17, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
Everyone
Platform(s)
PlayStation 5, PlayStation 4, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Xbox One, Nintendo Switch, PC, Android, iOS
Powered by

Wingspan brings the award-winning board game of bird-collecting to digital life, pairing soothing visuals and real bird calls with deeply rewarding engine-building gameplay. Here, async multiplayer isn’t just an option; it’s a beautifully integrated core, allowing up to five players to build preserves and outmaneuver each other on flexible schedules across platforms.

What sets Wingspan apart is its polish: It comes with seamless notifications, intuitive UI, and a community that’s both welcoming and competitive. The experience is as relaxing as it is strategic, making every turn a moment to savor. Wingspan proves that a compelling strategy game doesn't need conflict, and it does so by offering a top-tier, uniquely relaxing asynchronous experience.

3 Root

A Masterclass in Asymmetrical Design And Flawless Execution

  • Platforms: PC, iOS, Android
  • Released: August 20, 2020
  • Developer: Dire Wolf Digital
  • Genre: Strategy, Simulation

Root is a landmark achievement that blends radical asymmetry, polished asynchronous multiplayer, and joyful chaos. Every faction plays by different rules, demanding unique strategies and constant adaptation. The digital adaptation nails the challenge, presenting all the complexity with a clean, intuitive UI and seamless cross-platform play.

Notifications, turn management, and visual flair combine to make Root a masterclass in asynchronous design. With a thriving player base, top-tier ratings, and both the board game and digital adaptation earning industry awards, Root pushes the boundaries for what the genre can achieve.

2 Clash Of Clans

The Mobile Strategy Titan That Mastered The Art Of Asynchronous Gaming

Clash of Clans
7.0 /10
Released
August 2, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Platform(s)
Android, iOS
Powered by

Clash of Clans is the blueprint for a mobile strategy that never sleeps. Its signature twist is that bases can be attacked by real players at any time, whether the defender is online or not. This compels players to log back in frequently, not just to build their own army, but to check on their base, collect resources, and re-arm traps.

On the flip side, attacking requires smart troop deployment and tactical timing. Add in the social layer—Clan Wars, donations, and team battles, and CoC becomes a living world where strategy and community collide. It’s one of the most downloaded and highest-rated mobile games ever, proof that a well-crafted async system can hook millions for years.

1 Chess.com

The Undisputed King Of Digital Chess

  • Platforms: PC, iOS, Android
  • Released: May 2007
  • Developers: Erik Allebest and Jarom "Jay" Severson
  • Genre: Strategy

Chess.com is the reigning champion of online chess, featuring a user base that dwarfs entire countries. Its asynchronous “Daily Chess” mode is the format’s gold standard, boasting massive active player pools, regular tournaments, and seamless cross-platform play. There’s always a game waiting, whether it’s a slow-burning rivalry or a casual matchup with someone halfway around the world.

Beyond the basics, Chess.com packs in a variety of features: video lessons from top coaches, deep analytical tools, social clubs, and professional tournaments streamed to millions. Its scale, network effect, and relentless focus on innovation have cemented its top spot as the best asynchronous multiplayer game out there.

item.title: The Different Types Of RPGs, Explained
item.description:
Summary

  • RPGs encompass diverse categories like ARPGs, TRPGs, and MMORPGs with unique gameplay styles and mechanics.
  • JRPGs and WRPGs differ in storytelling, character development, and gameplay design, catering to various player preferences.
  • Action RPGs offer fast-paced combat, while turn-based RPGs provide sequential gameplay with strategic elements for deeper challenges.

When it comes to the various types of games and their genres, the RPG is one of the most popular, diverse, and longest-standing categories in the industry. From having fast-paced, action-packed gameplay to focusing on slower, more strategic mechanics, there is a wide range of options for every type of player.

Nearly all role-playing games share the same core concepts familiar to the genre, but there are many different categories and subgenres of RPGs, each with its own distinct design and gameplay elements that set them apart. Suffice it to say, it can be downright confusing for those looking to dive into the genre for the first time.

1 JRPG vs. WRPG

Regional RPG Differences

To start, there are two main categories of role-playing game styles, those being Japanese RPGs and Western RPGs. Both follow the same typical RPG blueprint anyone would expect, but they have their own design differences.

As the name suggests, JRPGs started out in Japan, and tend to focus on their stories and character building with more of an emotional component worked into both, often containing a bit more of a semi-linear plot. WRPGs tend to offer a more open-ended experience, where the player forges their own journey as they see fit.

That's not to say that one is better than the other, though; it's purely based on the player’s personal preference of which style they may enjoy more. Both of these categories of RPG can vary widely in their gameplay styles, which are covered in more detail below.

Examples:

JRPGs: Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest, Persona

WRPGs: The Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age, Ultima

2 Action RPGs (ARPG)

Fast-Paced, Action-Packed Combat

The subgenre of action role-playing games isn’t the oldest, but it is easily one of the most common today, with many of the biggest names in the RPG genre being action-based.

ARPGs are often considered easier to get into and learn the mechanics of, depending on the game. They often feature fast-paced, real-time combat that can focus on chaining attacks together for combos, or simply a button-mashing, hack-and-slash experience. It's one of the more approachable RPG subgenres out there, being relatively easy to pick up with some exceptions, like Soulslike games, for example.

Examples: The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim, Elden Ring, Mass Effect 3

3 Turn-Based RPGs

Sequential Gameplay With A Variety Of Options

Onto the category of turn-based role-playing games, and it seems like a rather self-explanatory title. But the subgenre can vary pretty widely in what sort of formula they use, how gameplay operates, and the overall difficulty.

At its core, combat alternates between player and opponent, while most of the game’s exploration happens in real-time in a sort of “overworld.” But over the years, there have been many different twists on the formula, with some having no time limit on turns and others requiring a waiting period between moves or attacks. For example, some of the early Final Fantasy titles were true turn-based combat, where turns alternate sequentially with no time limit. But the series has also adopted an ATB (Active Time Battle) system, which factors in skills and effects for turn order and timing.

Examples: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, Persona 5, Paper Mario

4 Tactical RPGs (TRPG)

Slow & Strategic Battles

Tactical roleplaying games may share many similarities with the previous subgenre in usually featuring sequential combat. But they may appeal to players who want a bit more of a challenge with deeper systems.

Where turn-based RPGs mostly focus on the combat and abilities, TRPGs mix in the element of unit positioning, which can greatly affect the outcome of each battle. The subgenre commonly follows similar mechanics with a few differences, especially regarding difficulty. Some have straightforward and beginner-friendly mechanics, while others focus much more on in-depth unit management, making for some downright tough gameplay throughout. TRPGs are not exclusively turn-based either, with titles like Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun and Commandos taking place in real-time.

Examples: XCOM 2, Final Fantasy Tactics, Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun

5 Computer RPGs (CRPG)

The Classic Roleplaying Experience

Computer role-playing games usually denote titles that follow a similar style and mechanics of RPGs from the 1990s and 2000s on the PC platform, hence the category is also commonly referred to as “Classic RPGs.”

The gameplay of older CRPGs commonly followed a turn-based formula from an isometric or overhead perspective, but the subgenre isn’t exclusive to one style of gameplay or viewpoint. Some iconic CRPGs from the 1990s, such as Ultima, Icewind Dale , or Jagged Alliance , follow a turn-based battle system, where others, like Diablo, System Shock 2 , or Daggerfall , feature action-based combat in real-time. The defining point that all of these CRPGs share is their focus on a player’s build and skills, which can influence combat and other interactions much more than other role-playing games.

Examples: Baldur's Gate 3, Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader, Planescape: Torment

6 Massively Multiplayer Online RPGs (MMORPG)

Bringing The RPG Experience Online With Thousands Of Other Players

Massively Multiplayer Online RPGs are some of the most popular titles in the larger role-playing genre, with even some of the oldest MMOs garnering tens of millions of players across the world to this day.

The core of MMORPGs has remained the same, the online component, and with all the different MMOs that have emerged over the years, the subgenre has a wide selection of different experiences to offer. From the classic medieval fantasy Runescape ’s world of Gielinor, to the high-tech, space-exploration of EVE Online ’s New Eden. Further than variety, MMORPGs also offer a large amount of content to explore, with many of the games expanding with a consistent flow of updates.

Examples: Runescape, World of Warcraft, Elder Scrolls Online

7 Roguelike / Roguelite RPGs

Hardcore RPGs With Little In The Way Of Hand-Holding

When it comes to Roguelike and Roguelite RPGs, the main similarities between both include the use of procedural (randomly generated) levels, and oftentimes requiring a fair amount of practice and skill in comparison to more traditional RPGs.

The original "Roguelike" games typically focused on dungeon-crawling with grid-based movement through randomized levels, oftentimes featuring perma-death to create an even tougher experience. The newer “Roguelite” category of games is very similar, but tends to contain extra features and options to make the experience more approachable and less punishing, like offering carry-over progression between playthroughs.

Examples: Hades, Dead Cells, Mystery Dungeon Series

item.title: RPGs Carried By Their Characters
item.description:
Summary

  • RPGs traditionally rely on strong characters and stories, with Star Wars: KOTOR 2 , The Witcher 2 , and Tyranny all serving as great examples.
  • While lacking in some areas, memorable characters from Dragon Age 2 or Vampyr elevate the overall RPG experience.
  • Games like Mass Effect: Andromeda and Final Fantasy 15 may not be the best in their series, but they do not deserve to be entirely overlooked.

Story and characters are at the core of any RPG, no matter if players have their own squad to manage or travel alone, only meeting other characters throughout the journey. Depending on how fleshed out and intriguing these aspects of the role-playing game are, characters alone can elevate otherwise unremarkable RPGs, providing enough reason for players to stick with a game until the very end.

Below, we'll take a look at some RPGs that are mostly carried by their characters and their twisted personal stories. These games typically aren't ranked among the best or the worst the genre has to offer, but their characters are arguably the best part of the entire experience.

Star Wars: Knights Of The Old Republic 2 – The Sith Lords

Kreia, Darth Nihilus, And Darth Sion

Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic 2: The Sith Lords
8.8 /10
Released
December 6, 2004

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Mild Blood, Mild Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 2 – The Sith Lords suffered from an extremely short development time, leading to numerous technical issues and ending up almost identical to its iconic predecessor gameplay-wise. However, Obsidian's focus on story, characters, and strong writing delivered one of the most nuanced and layered narratives in all of Star Wars to date.

A large part of the game's charm belongs specifically to the titular Sith Lords: Darth Traya (Kreia) and her apprentices, Darth Nihilus and Darth Sion. Traveling aboard the Ebon Hawk alongside Kreia, learning about her past, personal goals, and perception of the Force, is a definite highlight of KOTOR 2 , along with the epic standoffs against other Dark Lords, each of whom has their own agenda.

Dragon Age 2

From Varric And Isabela To Aveline, Merrill, And Fenris

Dragon Age 2
7 /10
8.3 /10
Released
March 8, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
Mature // Blood and Gore, Language, Sexual Content, Violence
Powered by

Another example of a potentially great RPG suffering from a very short development time, Dragon Age 2 is among the most divisive in the series to date. While the sequel's limited scope, uneven combat system, and copy-pasted environments may have their skeptics, this is hardly true for the game's story and characters.

The personal journey of Hawke through the years in Kirkwall proves a strong foundation for another chapter in the Dragon Age universe, while the supporting cast and companions, like in The Sith Lords , are the heart of the game, staying true to BioWare's high standards. For some players, Dragon Age 2 has become one of the all-time favorite RPGs, full of human moments and gut-wrenching choices, with companions like Merrill, Isabela, and Fenris ranking among BioWare's best.

Tyranny

Barik, Verse, Eb, And Sirin Versus Great Kyros' Generals

Tyranny
9 /10
Released
November 10, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Powered by

Unlike the Pillars of Eternity games that get their continuation in Avowed , Tyranny proved less successful for Obsidian, despite its fully original world and the premise of playing as one of the evil Overlord Kyros' judges, known as the Fatebinders. The game ended on an intriguing cliffhanger, and while it's unlikely to ever receive a sequel at this point, that's not a reason to skip Tyranny entirely.

True to form, Obsidian's writing and focus on characters shine through, delivering complex questlines with unpredictable outcomes, a great deal of freedom, and player choice when it comes to almost any key character in the story, as well as strong companions and villains alike. Every action in Tyranny yields consequences, allowing players to shape the personalities of their followers, and some of the twists involving Barik or Sirin are hard to forget.

The Witcher 2: Assassins Of Kings

Geralt, Triss, And Vernon Roche Chasing Iorveth And Letho

The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings (Enhanced Edition)
RPG
Systems
Released
April 17, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
M // Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs
Powered by

Back in the day, when CD Projekt Red was yet to be hailed as one of the world's leading RPG developers, The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings made much less of an impact than the third entry, despite plenty of strengths. Drawing from the books and adding a flair of their own, the studio delivered perfect renditions of now-iconic characters like Geralt of Rivia, Dandelion, and Triss Merigold, while also presenting greatly fleshed-out and fully original characters such as the leader of the Blue Stripes, Vernon Roche, elven Scoia'tael leader Iorveth, and mysterious witcher antagonist Letho.

When it comes to characters, The Witcher 2 fully delivers, placing players at the center of crucial story-defining choices like who to trust and who to follow, changing perspectives throughout by briefly allowing them to take the role of other key characters like Prince Stennis or King Henselt, and portraying a morally complex story where everything that happens has long-reaching consequences.

Final Fantasy 15

Noctis, Prompto, Ignis, And Gladiolus

Final Fantasy 15
9 /10
8.3 /10
Released
November 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Language, Mild Blood, Partial Nudity, Violence
Powered by

Final Fantasy 15 is often regarded as one of the most troubled games in the legendary franchise, failing to fully deliver on its unique world and premise. Even after years of addressing the game's issues post-launch, FF15 remains far from the best entries in the series, yet it is not without some redeeming qualities. Unsurprisingly, the central characters and their dynamics throughout the story are one such highlight.

From the very first moments, it's apparent that Noctis and his friends-slash-bodyguards Prompto, Ignis, and Gladiolus are in for an epic and lengthy journey, full of dramatic twists, heartfelt revelations, and mundane yet relatable moments. The first half of the game, where the group of friends travels around the world, is often described as the best that Final Fantasy 15 has to offer.

Mass Effect: Andromeda

From Cora Harper And Liam Kosta To Jaal And Peebee

Mass Effect: Andromeda
8 /10
10
8.4 /10
Released
March 1, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Violence
Powered by

Mass Effect: Andromeda was bound to live in the shadow of the original trilogy focused on Commander Shepard, but the game isn't as irredeemable as many fans still believe. After all the dust settled, Andromeda not only boasts the most fast-paced and dynamic combat in the series and some of the best explorable worlds, but also offers plenty of intriguing characters, some of which can rival the beloved companions of its predecessors.

While the new Tempest crew may lack the perfect character dynamics of the first Mass Effect games, every new companion, be it Liam Kosta, Nakmor Drack, or Vetra Nyx, has a place in the story, as well as several personal quests, all of which are among the game's most memorable missions. If only Mass Effect: Andromeda had a villain even slightly as fleshed out as Saren or the Illusive Man to make its story more exciting.

Vampyr

Jonathan E. Reid Surrounded By Potential Victims

Vampyr
5 /10
8.6 /10
Released
June 5, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language, Use of Drugs
Powered by

Vampyr is a unique breed of dialogue-heavy RPG, notable for several reasons, story and characters included. From the morally tormented protagonist Jonathan E. Reid, who becomes a bloodthirsty vampire, to a plethora of other well-established characters that players may kill or spare, all backed by strong writing, Vampyr can become a truly immersive and meaningful experience despite some of the game's shortcomings.

Ultimately, Vampyr lives or dies by how invested players are in the story and how eager they are to learn more about every character, like Edgar Swansea or Sean Hampton, to make deliberate choices regarding their fate. The game might be demanding to get into, but for players who can appreciate a nuanced and slow-paced, almost detective-like central narrative full of complex themes, Vampyr hardly disappoints.

item.title: Legendary Developer Ron Gilbert Reveals New Game at Gamescom ONL
item.description:
Death by Scrolling is the name of the latest game by legendary developer Ron Gilbert. Unveiled during the 2025 edition of Gamescom, Death by Scrolling is currently only confirmed for PC.

Ron Gilbert is an American developer best known as the creator of the Monkey Island series. He started his career at Lucasfilm Games in the 1980s and has over 100 credits to his name, including work on Maniac Mansion , Total Annihilation: The Core Contingency , Ollo in the Sunny Valley Fair , and The Big Big Castle . Most recently, the industry veteran co-designed, directed, and wrote Return to Monkey Island , the sixth installment in his most popular franchise, debuted in 2022.

Death by Scrolling Premieres at Gamescom 2025

Gilbert's latest project was unveiled during Gamescom 2025 Opening Night Live in the form of Death by Scrolling . Behind that whimsical name is a chaotic experience that combines elements of roguelike and bullet hell games. The moniker itself refers to the game's perspective, as Death by Scrolling will have players moving through vertically scrolling environments. Retreat won't be an option because the Grim Reaper will always be hot on their heels, looking to end their run.

The presence of the Grim Reaper reflects the game’s broader themes, as Death by Scrolling is set in Purgatory, an unusual place that appears to be an amalgamation of different mythologies’ interpretations of death and the afterlife. Souls trapped there must pay 10,000 gold pieces to a Ferryman, described in-game as an "exorbitant" fee, before moving on. To raise the sum, they must undertake multiple runs through the ever-shifting world of Purgatory, establishing the foundation for Death by Scrolling ’s roguelike gameplay loop.

Death by Scrolling will feature multiple playable characters, retro pixel art graphics, and online leaderboards. Gilbert’s stamp on the game will materialize in the form of witty, tongue-in-cheek dialogue. While players will constantly be urged to keep running upward, the announcement trailer shows that doing so blindly may not guarantee safety, as the Grim Reaper can also appear from above.

Prior to its Gamescom 2025 premiere, Death by Scrolling was teased by Gilbert himself in late 2024, when he said his studio, Terrible Toybox, planned to launch it in the coming months. While this launch target has clearly slipped since then, the company's official website presently lists Death by Scrolling as being planned for a late 2025 release. The upcoming title, set to be published by MicroProse Software, has so far only been announced for PC.
